This gives me an interesting idea...

Imagine a program that takes in a network definition, analyzes it, and 
produces optimized C code for processing it.  Suppose you had a domain (like 
the one I'm looking at) where network activation is very much the bulk of 
the time.  Something like that would allow the experiment to run much 
faster.

Of course, a more realistic approach is to store information about how to 
rapidly calculate a network result along with the network.  Then, you can 
activate the network as many times as you need to, optimally.  You simply 
have an initial overhead cost of the analysis and 'strategy' determination.

No, such a thing is definitely overkill for xor.  But for image enlargement, 
where analyzing the fitness of a single network may involve billions (yes, 
billions) of activations, every little bit will help.

Anybody read anything applicable to 'optimized neural network calculation'?  
Maybe have some suggestions on things to read up on?  :)

>From: Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...>

>That is true, and could be useful if the method in
>NEAT was slow for some application.  One could take
>the topology and weights that were evolved, and then
>write code to implement it in a speedy manner.
